reviewText: Finally a program that was built from scratch and not based on a book or writer. They can not do it wrong because this is it. Looks like there is more horticulture than in the Brother Cadfael series.Two women, each have a Life changing experience just before the series starts. Soon they become friends.  One a hands on gardener, with a law enforcement back ground Laura Thyme, (Pam Ferris), the other an academic horticulturist with an old four wheeler vehicle Rosemary Boxer (Felicity Kendal).The programs are of the two trying to find out who dunnit and how. We do not get bogged down in love interests.Each episode is unique in its approach. The only pattern I see is that it is like in the movie "A shot in the dark" where everyone is guilty except the maid. In this series there may not be a lit of murderers, however there are a lot of guilty people.Well sit back and enjoy the view, smell the roses, and buy the series so you can watch again and again.
summary: Do not have to compare to the book

reviewText: They are here, all the episodes.  VERY BRITISH.  You know, a scream now and then, throwing china against walls ------one must wonder if the secret conversations of such puritanical females bring up accounts of the number of teacups that met their end smashed to pieces for the sake of something to talk about.  Violent vanities seem to appeal rather than real life.While there are so many women in various roles, which I like, there are many personality situations.  Some are dreadful examples of destructive anger which seem to be some kind of normal behavior for the modern life of women.  Complaining, whining, man haters in the finest of old tradition of faultless female suffering which is never of their own making whether real or imagined though usually the latter.  Punching men seems to be a modern proper rite of womanhood in these gardens.Unlike the simpleton emotions of most of the male characters in these plots, who let the punch occur, I would defend myself from predatory females.  Self defense.It seems as much a study of Victorian Puritanism in many women including the main two doing the sluething.  Violence seems as much their style as those they uncover."To hell with men," agree the two in the first episode.  Emotional displays of anger and physical violence from both of them appear from time to time yet no remorse, completely unable to see the damage they do.As a try for humor I wish that somewhere in the episodes a character would say "My wife, no, no, she won't be here for the celebration, she can't stand the sight of people enjoying themselves, makes her sick for days."  It is an old joke that says much for the all-pure puritanical point of view.Anyway, I find it an extra, a well done screenplays full of human frailities at all levels.The acting is good in my opinion.  So is the music with basic themes.  Can't fault the scenery.  The smaller detective can look like a teenager in a bouncy bra and a pretty top.  Good for her.Episode One is a fine collection of psycho cases, especially men who believed the words of  killer women, thinking the female of the species is only made of sugar and spice and everything nice.Episode two has one our dynamic duo being shot at with bullets passing through a window while she goes into an anger which is finally expressed by her opening a door and yelling at the unknown shooter.  Not smart nor believable.  No search for bullets, no report.  Stupid.  It is a shame to display any woman that stupid.  Just an opinion.  Later they report it in a humerous incident which is clever.  But not real enough.Well, I'm not perfect either.  In series one, 2nd dvd, is a plot containing a dog who saves the life of one of the two of our girl stars.  And what does the doggy get for it?  A new life in a dog group home of some sort.  What?  What?  Well, these girl stars do seem to hate the world and take the hate out on we mere lowly humans and dogs.  Ruffled my feathers.  It's a secret plot theme perhaps.  Even the son of one of the girl stars seems to want to stay away from his mom.  Can't blame him or his father who now has a new 23 year old girl in his life.  I wonder what the older girl star did to him for years until he tossed her out?There is a fine number of rich arrogant snobs as well.  No vulgarity, well, of course not.Lots of wine and champagne.  Vases full of massive bouquets.Precious little pub grub.  No beer and sandwiches nor a ploughman lunch for our private detectives.  Quite uppity this duo.  Quite clean too often.In the last series we find a revolver being used in an unsafe way.  It may help a screenplay but idiotic firearm usuage is too stupid to accept as a good screenplay.That clever little poem spoken in a tent in the Elizabethan garden episode is a spicy gem.There is a little bit of carefully underplayed humor from time to time as in the housekeeper-cook who can't get better than putting a kettle on.  A grand character.  Just love her.There's always a dead body handy in a garden or a shed.  But not a pansy was injured nor a stock plant suffered disrespect.  Only the pride of the actors was trampled upon.  Shortage of daffodils is very upsetting.  Plenty of blooming idiots.
summary: unusual, good cinemaphotography, has subtitles, wide screen

reviewText: This series reminds me of a British version of Murder, She wrote. There are two delightful British women this time, one recently dumped by her husband for a younger woman, the other being suddenly fired. The two become friends and start solving mysteries, frequently by using clues given by plants and trees. I decided to watch it to see if I could learn any gardening secrets, or at least inspire myself to do better on my garden than I did last year. I love the scenery!Most of the time the action takes place in gorgeous English gardens, but one of my favorites was on the French Riviera and included stunning old French homes and gardens.It's an enjoyable collection.
summary: Charming Mystery Series With A Gardening Theme

reviewText: Most mystery series have big tough longtime cops or lovably eccentric oddballs as their detectives.So it's a bit refreshing to see a pair of utterly ordinary detectives in the light mystery series "Rosemary and Thyme" -- one a cop-turned-housewife, and one a feisty horticulturist. You won't find any mind-blowing mysteries, just solid whodunnits and likable characters... and plants. Lots and lots of beautiful plants.Laura Thyme (Pam Ferris) has just been dumped by her husband of 27 years, for a "twenty-three-year-old tart!" When visiting an old pal, she encounters plant pathologist Rosemary Boxer (Felicity Kendal) who is promptly fired by her slimy boss. The two wronged women team together to solve a bizarre mystery involving poisonous plants, a car wreck, and a serial killer.After that, Rosemary and Laura go into business together, treating sick lawns and creating picturesque gardens. But like any good detectives, they keep bumping into sinister crimes, both of the past and present: a spa matriarch is strangled at her desk, skeletons are uncovered in a murdered pop star's garden, and a man is killed in a graveyard... with an arrow.Things don't improve much in the following seasons -- Rosemary and Laura end up dealing with wrecked romantic gardens, Parisian theft and murder, school pranks gone wrong, Italian restaurants, ferocious competition at a garden show, murder at a vineyard, sabotaged plays and tennis camps.... and even an abandoned baby that may have something to do with a murder."Rosemary and Thyme" is notable more for its cozy, cottagey feel than for its intricate mysteries -- but then again, they don't try to be complex or twisty. Instead, the stories focus on our likable horticulturists, and the lovely gardens they create or restore... and the entertaining dialogue ("You've broken the bloody window!" Rosemary yells at a sniper) makes this even more fun.There's a pleasantly old-fashioned flavour to the series -- lots of vine-draped cottages, manorhouses, luxurious resorts, vineyards and herbal skills. Sure, there's laptops, TV shows, drug dealers and myriad cell phones. But those are just the trappings on an ordinary little mystery series, where the plant sicknesses often have something to do with the murders.Of course, the leads make or break a series like this. Fortunately, Kendal and Ferris have excellent chemistry. Laura and Rosemary are an entertaining pair, with just the right mix of similarities and differences. Laura is a sensible ex-cop/housewife who is still dealing with her family tensions, while Laura is a cultured academic ("more a bookworm than an earthworm") with a rough streak.Plant lovers and mystery buffs should enjoy the cozy, vine-covered mysteries of "Rosemary and Thyme." It's just fun and pleasant, all the way through.

reviewText: Rosemary Boxer and Laura Thyme are full time gardeners and part-time nosey parkers or is that the other way round?  Either way, I found this series delightful!  I began viewing this lovely series on PBS a few years ago but my area station carried them in a hit and miss fashion--more miss than hit, so I ordered the complete set!  I have not regretted it one bit!From the very first episode, When No Birds Sing, the characters of Laura Thyme (played by the amazingly talented Pam Ferris, most recently of Call the Midwife) and Rosemary Boxer (played by the equally brilliant Felicity Kendal) jumped off of the screen and into my heart.  The series begins with Laura leaving her home and well tended, much beloved garden.  Her husband, Nick, of 27 years has left her for a younger woman, a 23-year old, thin-as-a-rail blonde!  Laura moans, it isn't her fault she got old! To make matters worse, if they can get worse, she has no income.  She was once a Police Constable but has not worked in many years in order to raise her two children and run the home.  She takes her packed bags and goes to the home of her husband's best mate. He and his wife promptly, but with some sympathy, deposit her at a local inn.  Is it simply a coincidence or is it providence that Ms. Rosemary Boxer, a professor of plant pathology, is also staying at the very same inn?  I say providence, absolutely! Rosemary is in the area at the behest of her university to diagnose some diseased, old, and rare trees.To avoid any spoilers, as one must meet these two without knowing ahead of time what will happen next; I'll just say that the two find that they are a match made in heaven.  They are first brought together by the mysterious death of a person to whom they both have connections.  After the mystery is solved, it is their love of gardens and kindred spirits that keep them together. Laura tells Rosemary, "I don't miss my house at all but I really miss my garden!"They form a business partnership and travel hither and yon to work their gardening magic.  Along the way, these feisty, women of a "certain age," who are suspicious of anything and anyone that strikes them as odd (and lucky for us that includes every single person they meet; people drop dead everywhere they go, friends and foes alike.) They solve murders while they garden. They are fearless, unabashed nosey parkers extraordinaire.  Together they are formidable and brazenly go around poking their collective noses into everyone's business.For me, it is a huge bonus that their gardening takes them to some breath-taking locales, which is the "scene of the crime" in each episode.  I don't care that it seems unbelievable that the two of them could pull off the masterpieces in botanical achievement that they do; I love these gardens! I want one! If you love English gardens, you will love those shown in this series.  Rosemary and Laura create and recreate a beautiful garden in each episode. Every scene includes stunning flower arrangements; hanging baskets dripping with blooms from every visible eave, even those attached to falling down sheds; historical ancient gardens (one of their restored gardens results in the visit by the Queen!) and flowers and plants of every color, kind and description imaginable.  The scenery is eye-popping. At solving murders, they turn out to be equally brilliant albeit there are some scrapes, bruises, twists, turns, stumbles, and a lot of luck involved along the way; lucky crime solving and lucky narrow escapes.  All in all, a lot of fun to watch! I'd love for Rosemary and Thyme to work a bit of their gardening magic at my home but I don't want anyone I know to be murdered!The ensuing episodes, 23 in all, offer delightful and entertaining mysteries without graphic forensics.
summary: Intrepid Nosey Parkers Who Just Happen To Be Brilliant Gardeners!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Rosemary & Thyme is a British mystery series staring Felicity Kendal (Good Neighbors, The Camomille Lawn) and Pam Ferris (Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban, Matilda) as gardening detectives. I first saw Felicity Kendal in Good Neighbors and fell in love with her sense of humor and personality. I was thrilled to find out that she brings that same down to earth personality to Rosemary & Thyme.  Rosemary & Thyme  was first aired on British television in 2003 and ran until August 2007.Both women are avid gardeners who are somehow embroiled in a bunch of different mysteries.  Laura Thyme (Pam Ferris) is the daughter of a farmer and former police woman who loves her home garden. Her husband recently left her for another woman so she has extra time on her hands. Rosemary Boxer (Felicity Kendal) has a degree in plant pathology and was recently laid off from her University job by her underhanded ex-beau.The series begins with Rosemary investigating some dying trees at the home of a friend.  Laura's husband has just left her for a younger woman and she finds herself in the same hotel as Rosemary.  They meet and uncover a plot to kill Rosemary's friend.  Rosemary and Thyme consider themselves gardeners more than they consider themselves detectives.  The mysteries just happen to occur where they are solving a gardening problem or creating a new garden and they get involved in finding clues for the mystery as well.  I love how  naturally each of these mysteries unravels.  It's very easy to think of these women as *just like you* especially since they are average middle aged women and not your typical Barbie doll style actress. The two women's personalities mesh together perfectly as friends.Most of the episodes take place in various manor houses and gardens in England however some are shot in other countries as well.  Just a few of the more famous locations include London's Kew Gardens and Regent's Park; the French Riveria; Italy's Ligurian coast; a Surrey vineyard; and the hills of Malaga, Spain.  Being able to see all of these lovely, exotic gardens was one of the reasons that I enjoyed these mysteries so much.  If you're a gardener yourself or someone who loves to watch travel programs, you'll want to watch this series just for the pleasure of seeing the different locations. If you're also a fan of British mysteries, all the better. You'll find this show a delightful break from the violence and reality shows on television now.Rosemary & Thyme: The Complete Collection includes all 22 episodes on 7 discs.  There is approximately 18 1/2 hours of viewing time.  Series 1 ran in 2003.  Series 2 ran in 2004.  Series 3 ran from 2005 to 2007. Extras include an interview with Felicity Kendal and Pam Ferris, production notes, location notes, and photo galleries.

reviewText: Ex-cop, Laura Thyme (Pam Ferris-`Little Dorrit' `Jane Eyre' `Darling Buds of May' `Middlemarch'), is a housewife who loses her husband to a younger woman. Rosemary Boxer (Felicity Kendal-`Edward the King' `Camomile Lawn'), lectures on horticulture, but looses her university job. An odd pairing, which began from very different pasts. Starting a business together makes sense till mystery, sometimes a death, appears around too many corners. Amateur sleuthing once again hits the British TV screen, not new, but this is definitely different. Not just for women. It's good mystery, good criminal policing, and of course beautiful scenic filming (not just England). Even the gardener's will like this action.SUBTITLES NOW.This is a re-release set of episodes. However this complete set, the entire "Rosemary and Thyme: Complete", 2011, now has SUBTITLES.Shows aired originally from 2003 to 2006. They are as contemporary as any today, and just fun to watch. A refreshing different angle to catch the crooks. This complete set is loaded with episodes. An economical way to own the entire series.__________Series 1- 6 episodes:And No Birds SingArabica and the Early SpiderThe Language of FlowersSweet AngelicaA Simple PlotThe Tree of Death__________Series 2- 8 episodes:The Memory of WaterOrpheus in the UndergrowthThey Understand Me in ParisThe Invisible WormThe GongoozlersThe Italian RapscallionSwords Into PloughsharesUp the Garden Path__________Series 3- 8 episodes:In a Monastery GardenSeeds of TimeAgua CadaverThree Legs GoodThe Gooseberry BushRacquet EspanolEnter Two GardenersThe Cup of Silence22 total episodes or over 18 hours of mysterious enjoyment.`

reviewText: If you love visiting beautiful gardens and love a good "who dun it" you will absolutely love "Rosemary and Thyme".  Rosemary Boxer and Laura Thyme are the most unlikely crime solvers I have ever encountered.  They have a business where they diagnose and cure horticultural problems but are most unfortunate in encountering dead bodies in the course of their work.  Rosemary, as the plant wiz, and Laura, as a former member of the police force, possess a charm, intelligence and outright funny way of dealing with both the horticultural and homicidal mayhem they encounter.  A very noticeable plus is that we get to view historic, world-wide acclaimed gardens as we follow them in their diagnosis, observations and conclusions on both these levels.  Another extraordinary British Granada Studios feature from PBS that will delight, inform and dazzle you and make you laugh, too.
summary: Beauty and Intrigue in the Garden

reviewerName: John D. Muir "oldies and pies lover"
reviewText: This is a nice British series. My wife and I are keen gardeners, so for us there is the added pleasure of seeing a series set in some lovely gardens.I do have a couple of reservations about it. First is personal; I've never really cared for Felicity Kendall. Ever since she came on the scene back in the 1970s with 'The Good Neighbors' (as it was titled in the US), she's always made me vaguely uncomfortable. She has a bit of a smug attitude, rather like the girl in school who knows she's the most popular girl of her year. I find Pam Ferris much more appealing; often she gets cast as someone nasty, like Aunt Marge in Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban or the terrifying school principal in Matilda, so it's nice to see her here as one of the good guys.My other slight misquiet is that the mysteries themselves are rather far-fetched. Trying to manufacture a crime in a garden setting and the involvement of two horticulturalists in the solving of the mystery needs some creative thinking on the part of those writing the screenplays, and it doesn't always come together very neatly. The locations are wonderful, the stories not so much- the plots are better than the plots, if you take my meaning.Still, it's beautiful and cosy and the theme music by John Williams (the classical guitarist, not the composer) is exqusite. Four stars might be stretching it a little, but as I said, my wife and I love gardens.

reviewText: If you love mystery stories this is a must to add to your collection.  These two women are delightful.  Rosemary (Boxer) meets (Laura) Thyme during a time in which each has experienced upsetting personal crises and they blend together as if they have been friends for years.  The friendship is just one reason to watch this series.  Although the two basically work as gardeners something always happens so that Thyme (a retired police office whose dirty bum of a husband dumps her for a younger woman AFTER she has given up her career to be a housewife) and Rosemary (whose dirty bum of a boyfriend has fired her from her job even after he has suggested they get back together) must get involved in investigations of murders which the police have bungled.  I have a problem with the way they interfere with the chain of custody of key pieces of evidence BUT this is fiction.  It is a bonus that the locations and sets are simply luscious with flowers and gorgeous trees and architecture of a Time Gone By.  The dialogue is a bit of a challenge in that the accents of the characters who are not well educated are somewhat difficult to understand but the shows are so enjoyable that I do not mind watching them a second time just to savor the entire experience.

reviewText: "Rosemary & Thyme" is a superbly crafted, richly produced, brilliantly acted, cleverly scripted series of mysteries featuring two intrepid (if unlikely) amateur female sleuths who are in the gardening and landscaping business but can't seem to avoid getting involved in murder mysteries. Laura Thyme (Pam Ferris) is a former policewoman who has been abandoned by her philandering husband for a younger woman, and Rosemary Boxer (Felicity Kendal) is a plant biologist who lost her university teaching post. Together they are Rosemary & Thyme, and their adventures are played out against gorgeous English gardens, manorial landscapes, and the often stunning floral beauty of rural Britain. Volume 1 features six episodes, while Volume 2 has eight episodes. These are classic British-style 'whodunnits' with the viewer deeply engaged with every remarkable character, plot twist, and surprise ending. The DVD format allows for the inclusion of production notes, a photo gallery, cast filmographies, - and even a trivia quiz. If a community library budget can only allow for the addition of one new DVD series - make it the enduringly popular, flawless produced, enthusiastically recommended "Rosemary & Thyme"!
summary: The enduringly popular, flawless produced, enthusiastically recommended "Rosemary & Thyme"!

Title: N/A

reviewText: I feel so distraught right now because I only have 3 more episodes to watch. I wish there were a hundred more. The casting of these great british actresses is spot on, and you can actually palpably feel the chemistry between them. I will cherish my Rosemery and Thyme collection for years to come, since I have this strange affliction that lets me remember if my experience with mysteries of all kinds, books, tv or movies was pleasurable, but a month or two later only remember that it was a wonderful experience, but I couldn't tell you how they turned out if my life depended on it.  But that just lets me watch it again and again and enjoy it every single time. I waited for a year to order this collection hoping against hope that it would come out on a blu-ray version. But I contacted Acorn and they explained since the series wasn't shot on actual film that a blu-ray collection would not be possible. But I was delighted to see that my dvds looked wonderful and all the glorious scenery looked just like that. Glorius. So get off the fence and order this collection today. Each day you delay you are missing out on a fabulous cozy mystery experience with two of the best British actresses around.  Enjoy!

reviewText: which is exactly the problem.I prefer mystery/police-procedural series with stories and characters with an edge; that are a little (or a lot) gritty; that are suspenseful, realistic and believable. This series offers none of that. The stories are lightweight and sanitized and, not surprisingly, rather boring. Each episode runs 46 minutes, about an hour less than an episode of, say, "Morse": too brief to develop stories with depth and complexity; too long for stories lacking those qualities.If the BBC were to commission Disney Studios to do a mystery series, "Rosemary & Thyme" might be the result. That isn't my cup of tea, but if it sounds like yours, enjoy!
summary: A series the whole family can watch...

Title: N/A

reviewText: As stated by many reviewers this is a mystery series that the whole family can watch. The characters of Rosemary Boxer and Laura Thyme are delightful and the two actresses, Felicity Kendall as Rosemary and Pam Ferris as Laura Thyme are perfect. The stories focus more on the characters than the murder, of which there is at least one per episode but it is not graphic or bloody. Kendall and Ferris seem to have the necessary chemistry to make the characters believable and their screen presence as good friend is genuine. Also the scenery in each episode is magnificent and is a large part of the series. I have read that filming the series takes place in many different gardens in England and there were two episodes shot in Europe, one in France and one in Italy. All in all a great series that is a pleasure to watch. I was sad to here that series 3 is the last and the show was dropped. I would really liked to have seen many more episodes. Highly recommended to anyone who likes "light" British mysteries that can be enjoyed by the whole family.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I loved this series!  Too bad it is so little known in the U.S.  The characters are likeable, and for the most part relate-able.  I found myself cheering at times when they got the "badies".  The places they go to garden are a treat to view!  I loved seeing so many English gardens and some estates.  There were also about 4 episodes filmed in other countries, 2 Spain, 1 Italy and 1 France, if they were in the locations they talked about on the show. (I was unable to find a filming locations page for these shows.)If you want totally realistic, maybe think twice.  While the writing was good, sometimes I was miles ahead figuring out who did it, sometimes their actions were not what you even think the character would do, and there were by far way to many murders in each episode to be realistic.  That being said, the stories overall made sense, were quite varied and I enjoyed the writing.Simon Langton, the director of the 1995 Pride and Prejudice also directed many of these episodes.  You'll also notice at least 4 people who played in '95 P&P; appear in various episodes here.  Also 1 person who was in the '80 P&P; that I noticed.I highly recommend this if you enjoy British filming, scenery, light mysteries and likeable characters.

reviewText: I first saw a few episodes of this series on PBS a couple of years ago, and enjoyed them, but when I checked to see if it was available on DVD I felt the price was more than I wanted to pay. So.....I rented all 3 seasons and totally enjoyed them.And I was pleasantly surprised recently when I found Amazon had the complete Collection at what I felt was a reasonable price.Finances out of the way, this series is delightful!!! Yes, every episode has a murder, and some are a bit gory, but the story lines are always interesting, and don't depend on the gory details (if they exist) to hold your attention.These 2 women are hired each week to solve someone's gardening problems, and the locations alone make watching the worthwhile. Nature abounds in all it's glory as the back drop for every story. Most of them take place in the UK, but they travel a bit in a couple episodes.There are also interesting tidbits for anyone who loves digging in the dirt and planting gardens, between Rosemary's background in Horticulture and Laura (Thyme)'s love of gardening and her down-to-earth 'old housewives tales'.And - a gold star for the writers of the show - These gals are organic - no chemicals and pesticides - except as the 'villans' in the 'plot', pardon the pun.If you haven't 'met' these lovely women and their wit and humor, check them out. I've enjoyed watching the series again, now that I bought the set, and am sure I'll watch it many more times.

reviewText: I found this set by accident but was charmed immediately by this unlikely duo of gardeners who keep stumbling across bodies in the course of their work. reviewText: This is definitely one of my favorite television shows of all time. Along with David Suchet's portrayal of Poirot, and Jeremy Brett's (albeit a little over the top) Holmes, Rosemary and Thyme is the best mystery series I've seen. They are cozies and you warm right up to them. I wish they had made many more seasons! I heard the show was canceled because Pam Ferris and Felicity Kendal couldn't get along. This is hard to believe because they have great on screen chemistry as two gardening friends who solve the murders that spring up around them. My personal favorite episodes are And No Birds Sing, The Tree of Death, The Invisble Worm, Up the Garden Path, Swords Into Ploughshares, and The Memory of Water, although ALL of the episodes ride at a very close second.Love 'em! I wish producers would make more shows like this.
summary: Mysteries-- and charm-- grow around them!

reviewText: Had seen this on DVD previously from Netflix, and wanted my own copy to watch when I wanted. I jus t love this series, too bad that they didn't make more.
